note_models.name: Cloze-88141
Cloze

fields:
Thyroid hormones increase cardiac output 
by inducing synthesis (upregulation) of {{c1::β1 adrenergic}} receptors in the heart

β1 receptors mediate the effects on the SNS to increase HR, contractility, SV, CO

thus B1 blockers can be used to alleviate adrenergic symptoms in a thyroid storm

{{c1::Thyroid storm (Thyrotoxicosis)}} is a serious complication that occurs when hyperthyroidism is untreatened and 
worsened in the setting of acute stress (e.g. infection, trauma, surgery)

patient has a preexisting hyperthyroid disease (grave's or toxic multinodular goiter)

acute stress + hyperthyroidism leads to massive catecholamine surge --> symptoms
Thyroid storm presents with agitation, delirium, fever, {{c2::diarrhea}}, coma, and {{c1::tachyarrhythmia}} (cause of death)

What serum marker may be elevated in thyroid storm due to increased bone turnover?

{{c1::Alkaline phosphatase}}
May also see increased LFTs

What are the "4 P's" used to treat thyroid storm?

 1. {{c1::Propranolol}} (a beta-blocker)
 2. {{c1::Propylthiouracil}} 
 3. {{c2::Prednisolone}} (a corticosteroid)
 4. {{c2::Potassium iodide}} (Lugol iodine)

Propylthiouracil binds to thyroid peroxidase and thereby inhibits the conversion of iodide to iodine. Thyroid peroxidase normally converts iodide to iodine (via hydrogen peroxide as a cofactor) and also catalyzes the incorporation of the resulting iodide molecule onto both the 3 and/or 5 positions of the phenol rings of tyrosines found in thyroglobulin. Thyroglobulin is degraded to produce thyroxine (T4) and tri-iodothyronine (T3), which are the main hormones produced by the thyroid gland. Therefore propylthiouracil effectively inhibits the production of new thyroid hormones.


Glucorticoids These agents block conversion of T4 to T3. The use of corticosteroids has been associated with improved survival. Stress doses are required to replace accelerated production and degradation of cortisol induced by TH.

This agent is used to inhibit TH release from the thyroid gland
{{c2::Myxedema}} is the accumulation of {{c1::glycosaminoglycans}} in the skin and soft tissue; it is most often associated with {{c3::hypothyroidism}}

the major GAG is hyaluronic acid, which then draws water out into the deposit (in interstitial spaces of the dermis; due to osmotic pressure) and causes swelling (water retention; usually facial / periorbital swelling but can be generalized nonpitting edema)

a myxedema coma = coma from hypothyroidism

In hypothyroidism patients, myxedema 
commonly affects the {{c1::larynx}} (causing deep voice) and {{c1::tongue}} (causing enlarged tongue)
3rd degree AV block can be caused by {{c1::Lyme}} disease

Which amino acid is the precursor to histamine? 

{{c1::Histidine}}

Converted by histidine decarboxylase; enzyme is active at room temperature which is why dark meat fish (which have symbiotic bacteria that produce a lot of this enzyme) that has been left out can result in scombroid poisoning
Methemoglobin has an {{c1::increased}} affinity for {{c2::cyanide}} relative to hemoglobin
useful for treating cyanide poisoning
Induced-{{c1::methemoglobinemia}} (i.e. {{c3::nitrites}} followed by {{c3::thiosulfate}}) may be used to treat {{c2::cyanide}} poisoning
Methemoglobin has a high affinity for cyanide (makes cyanmethemoglobin, and thiosulfate transforms cyanide to thiocyanate (which can be renally excreted)
{{c1::Retinopathy of prematurity}} is an eye complication associated with {{c2::supplemental O2}} therapy in NRDS patients (due to neovascularization)
may lead to blindness in neonates; also may be referred to as retrolental fibroplasia
{{c1::Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons}} and {{c2::arsenic}} are particularly mutagenic carcinogens found in cigarette smoke
Aspirin irreversibly inactivates the enzyme {{c1::cyclooxygenase}}, thus decreasing synthesis of {{c2::TXA2}} and impairing platelet {{c3::aggregation}}

Treatment for disorders of fibrinolysis is
 {{c1::aminocaproic acid}}, which blocks activation of {{c2::plasminogen}}
antidote for TPA
One treatment for cyanide poisoning is {{c1::sodium thiosulfate}}, which helps restore rhodanese-mediated metabolism of cyanide to thiocyanate

- normally, cyanide is metabolized in tissues by rhodanese (transfers a sulfur molecule to cyanide --> thiocyanite, less toxic and excreted in the urine); cyanide overdose depletes the available sulfur donors allowing cyanide to accumulate

- sodium thiosulfate works by providing additional sulfur groups for rhodanese enhancing cyanide detox
In high doses, {{c1::aspirin}} may act as an uncoupling agent of oxidative phosphorylation
Vitamin {{c2::C}} keeps iron in the {{c1::Fe2+}} state which {{c3::increases}} absorption
Bad in iron toxicity
{{c1::Arsenic}} is a heavy metal that causes glycolysis to produce zero net ATP
Symptoms of acute {{c3::arsenic}} toxicity include vomiting, {{c1::rice-water}} stools, {{c2::garlic}} breath, and {{c4::QT}} prolongation
found in many pesticides/insectides and contaminated water; long term can cause alteration in pigementation / hyperkeratosis because arsenic likes to bind to cysteine residues in keratin

Which "Tender Loving Care for Nancy" cofactor is inhibited by arsenic? 

{{c1::Lipoic acid}}

Binds to sulfhydryl groups, imparing cellular respiration via inhibiting PDH; also disrupts gluconeogenesis and glutathione metabolism

results in pigmentary skin changes, skin cancer, vomiting, diarrhea, QT prolongation, garlic breath
Lead (Pb) poisoning leads to inhibition of the enzymes {{c1::δ-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase}} and {{c2::ferrochelatase}} (heme synthesis)

Sketchy Pharmacology: Autonomics (β blockers) 

β-blocker toxicity is treated with {{c1::glucagon}}, saline, or atropine

Glucagon has receptors on the heart and stimulates the Gs cascade (leading to increased Ca release from intracellular stores and increased SA firing), therefore it bypasses the Beta receptor Gs blockade
{{c2::Sideroblastic}} anemia may be caused by {{c1::lead}} poisoning
lead denatures the enzymes ALAD and ferrochelatase
{{c1::Primary CNS}} lymphoma typically presents as a single, solid brain lesion on MRI

may be ring-enhancing in immunocompromised patient; versus multiple ring enhancing lesions in toxoplasmosis 

Primary CNS depicted below:

Toxo depicted below:
Primary CNS lymphoma must be distinguished from {{c1::toxoplasmosis}} infection via CSF analysis or other lab tests
single, solid lesion (lymphoma) vs multiple, ring-enhancing lesions (toxoplasmosis)
Wernicke encephalopathy is characterized by a triad of {{c1::confusion}}, {{c2::ophthalmoplegia}}, and {{c3::ataxia}}
may also have nystagmus
{{c2::Korsakoff}} syndrome is a late manifestion of Wernicke encephalopathy characterized by {{c1::confabulations}}, irreversible memory loss, and personality changes
Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is associated with {{c1::thiamine (B1)}} deficiency and excessive {{c2::alcohol}} use
In addition to group B streptococci, neonatal meningitis is also commonly caused by {{c1::E. coli}} and {{c2::Listeria monocytogenes}} infection
The most common cause of meningitis in adults and the elderly is {{c1::Streptococcus pneumoniae}} infection
Gram +

Meningitis presents with a classic triad of:

- altered {{c3::level of consciousness}}
- {{c1::nuchal}} rigidity
- {{c2::high fever}}
headache, photophobia (especially with viruses), and vomiting may also be present
Diagnosis of meningitis is made by {{c1::lumbar puncture}}

- suspected bacterial meningitis require urgent blood cultures, empiric antibiotics, LP with CSF

- make a Center Line between iliac crests = fourth lumbar vertebral body; Perform by placing needle between L4/L5 (L4/5 interspace used (this is because its well below the termination of the cord (L1/2))

What opening pressure (lumbar puncture) is associated with bacterial meningitis? 

{{c1::Increased pressure}}
Bacterial meningitis is associated with significantly increased {{c1::Neutrophils}} (cell type) in the CSF
Fungal, TB, Viral meningitis and HSV encephalitis only have moderately increased levels of CSF cells in comparison
Bacterial meningitis is associated with {{c1::increased}} protein in the CSF
Bacterial meningitis is associated with {{c1::decreased}} glucose in the CSF

Which type of meningitis presents with decreased sugar and increased PMNs in the CSF?

{{c1::Bacterial meningitis}}
Fungal/TB meningitis is associated with increased {{c1::lymphocytes}} (cell type) in the CSF
Fungal/TB meningitis is associated with {{c1::increased}} protein in the CSF
Fungal/TB meningitis is associated with {{c1::decreased}} glucose in the CSF

Which type of meningitis presents with decreased sugar and increased lymphocytes in the CSF?

{{c1::Fungal/TB meningitis}}

What opening pressure (lumbar puncture) is associated with viral meningitis? 

{{c1::Normal}} or {{c1::increased pressure}}
Viral meningitis is associated with {{c1::normal}} glucose in the CSF
important distinguishing feature from bacterial and fungal/TB meningitis

Which type of meningitis presents with normal sugar and increased lymphocytes in the CSF?

{{c1::Viral meningitis}}
Complications of meningitis are classically seen with {{c1::bacterial}} meningitis and are a result of the massive {{c2::inflammatory}} response in the CSF

- These include seizures, focal neurologic deficits, hearing loss, communicating high pressure hydrocephalus (due to inflammation and scarring of arachnoid villi)

- Gram + bacterial macromolecules (teichoic acid, peptidoglycan) released from cell lysis trigger release of inflammatory cytokines (TNFa, IFN-y, IL-12) that loosen the tight junctions of the BBB, leading to vasogenic edema, elevation of intracranial pressure, and recruitment of leukocytes
Bacterial meningitis may cause death due to {{c1::herniation}}, secondary to cerebral edema
cerebral edema occurs with bacterial meningitis due to pus and exudate
Meningitis is treated empirically with {{c1::ceftriaxone}} and {{c2::vancomycin}}; add {{c3::ampicillin}} if Listeria is suspected
{{c1::Dementia}} is defined as decreased cognitive ability, memory, or function with intact consciousness
Dementia is a common feature of {{c1::late}} (early or late) Parkinson disease
important distinguishing feature from Lewy body dementia (where dementia occurs before parkinsonism)
{{c4::Normal pressure}} hydrocephalus classically presents with a triad of {{c1::urinary incontinence}}, {{c2::gait apraxia}}, and {{c3::dementia}}

"wet, wobbly, and wacky"; sometimes reversible

- urinary incontinence is caused by disruption of the periventricular pathways that transmit inhibitory impulses from the cortex to the sacral micturition center

- apraxia is a motor disorder caused by damage to the posterior parietal cortex, where the individual has difficulty with motor planning to perform tasks / movements (without sensory loss or paralysis)
The most common cause of meningitis in children is {{c1::Streptococcus pneumoniae}} infection
Gram +

Which nervous system cell is typically damaged by Guillain-Barre syndrome? 

{{c1::Schwann cells}}

Which movement disorder presents as "flapping" motion upon extension of the wrists? 

{{c1::Asterixis}}
Asterixis is associated with hepatic {{c1::encephalopathy}}, Wilson disease, and other metabolic derangements
Metabolic encephalopathies are associated with asterixis

Which peripheral nerve layer contains inflammatory infiltrate in Guillain-Barre syndrome? 

{{c1::Endoneurium}}
Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculopathy is the most common subtype of {{c1::Guillain-Barre}} syndrome
{{c2::Guillain-Barre}} syndrome results in symmetric {{c1::ascending}} muscle weakness/paralysis (ascending or descending)
sometimes may involve sensory abnormalities as well
Guillain-Barre syndrome is associated with {{c1::decreased}} DTRs beginning in the lower extremities

GBS is thought to result from an immune response to a preceding infection that cross-reacts with peripheral nerve components because of molecular mimicry. The immune response can be directed towards the myelin or the axon of peripheral nerve, resulting in demyelinating and axonal forms of GBS
Guillain-Barre syndrome may be associated with cardiopulmonary irregularities and fluctuations in {{c1::blood pressure}} (autonomic dysfunction)
- Respiratory depression (paralysis of repsiratory muscles) is typically what causes fatality
Guillain-Barre syndrome is associated with {{c1::increased}} CSF protein and {{c2::normal}} cell count, which may cause papilledema
increased CSF + normal cell count is known as an albuminocytologic dissociation

The bugs that are associated with Guillain-Barre Syndrome are ICE MyCZ:

I{{c1::nfluenzavirus}}
C{{c2::MV}}
E{{c3::BV}}

My{{c4::coplasma Pneumoniae}}
C{{c5::ampylobacter}}
Z{{c6::ika}}
In addition to post-viral/bacterial infection, Guillain-Barre syndrome also may arise due to {{c1::vaccination}} or stress

Guillain–Barré syndrome (GBS) is a rapid-onset muscle weakness caused by the immune system damaging the peripheral nervous system.[2] The initial symptoms are typically changes in sensation or pain along with muscle weakness, beginning in the feet and hands.
{{c1::Respiratory}} support is critical until recovery for patients with Guillain-Barre syndrome
In addition to respiratory support, Guillain-Barre syndrome may be treated with {{c1::plasmapheresis}} and IV {{c2::immunoglobulins}}

Are steroids useful in the management of Guillain-Barre syndrome? 

{{c1::No}}

Which psychiatric disorder, delirium or dementia, is characterized by acute onset "waxing and waning" level of consciousness? 

{{c1::Delirium}}

Which psychiatric disorder, delirium or dementia, is characterized by decreased intellectual function without affecting level of consciousness? 

{{c1::Dementia}}

Is dementia typically reversible or irreversible? 

{{c1::Irreversible}}

Which psychiatric disorder, delirium or dementia, is characterized by disorganized thinking, hallucinations, disturbances in sleep wake cycle, cognitive dysfunction, and agitation? 

{{c1::Delirium}}

Typically reversible

Visual hallucinations typically = medical

Which psychiatric disorder, delirium or dementia, is characterized by memory deficits, apraxia, aphasia, agnosia, behavioral/personality changes, and impaired judgment? 

{{c1::Dementia}}

Can a patient with dementia develop delirium? 

{{c1::Yes}}
e.g. a patient with Alzheimer disease who develops pneumonia is at increased risk for delirium

{{c1::Delirium}} (dementia or delirium) is usually secondary to other illness (e.g. CNS disease, infection, trauma, substance abuse/withdrawal, metabolic disturbances, hemorrhage, urinary/fecal retention)
{{c2::Dementia}} (dementia or delirium) is associated with a {{c1::normal}} pattern on EEG
{{c1::Delirium}} (dementia or delirium) is the most common presentation of altered mental status in an inpatient setting (especially in the ICU and with prolonged hospital stays)

What infectious disease is an irreversible cause of dementia? 

{{c1::HIV}}
{{c1::Tactile}} hallucinations are common in {{c2::alcohol}} withdrawal and stimulant use (e.g. cocaine, amphetamines)
e.g. delusional parasitosis (bugs under skin), "cocaine crawlies"

Sketchy Pharmacology: Neuro/Psych 

Arrhythmia secondary to tricyclic antidepressants is prevented with {{c1::NaHCO3}}

- increases serum pH and extracellular sodium, which alleviates fast sodium channel blockade

- TCAs are weak bases, and thus NaHCO3 will NOT aid elimination
Non-specific symptoms of {{c1::depressant}} intoxication (stimulant or depressant) include anxiolysis (relaxed), disinhibition, respiratory depression, and mood elevation
Non-specific symptoms of {{c1::depressant}} withdrawal (stimulant or depressant) include anxiety, tremor, insomnia, and seizures

What symptoms of alcohol withdrawal occur during the 3 - 36 hour time period? 

{{c1::Non-specific depressant withdrawal symptoms}}
e.g. anxiety, tremor, insomnia
The non-specific depressant symptoms of alcohol withdrawal usually occur {{c1::3}} to {{c1::36}} hours after the last drink

What symptoms of alcohol withdrawal occur during the 6 - 48 hour time period? 

{{c1::Withdrawal seizures}}
The seizures of alcohol withdrawal usually occur {{c1::6}} to {{c1::48}} hours after the last drink

What symptoms of alcohol withdrawal occur during the 12 - 48 hour time period? 

{{c1::Alcoholic hallucinosis (usually visual)}}
The alcoholic hallucinosis of alcohol withdrawal usually occurs {{c1::12}} to {{c1::48}} hours after the last drink

What symptoms of alcohol withdrawal may occur during the 48 - 96 hour time period? 

{{c1::Delirium tremens (5% of cases)}}
Delirium tremens, secondary to alcohol withdrawal, usually occurs {{c1::48}} to {{c1::96}} hours after the last drink
Delirium tremens is characterized by autonomic {{c1::hyper}}-activity
e.g. tachycardia, tremors, anxiety, seizures
Delirium tremens is characterized by electrolyte disturbances and respiratory {{c1::alkalosis::acidosis or alkalosis}}
Hyperventilation causes increased loss of PACO2
Delirium tremens classically occurs in a {{c1::hospital}} setting
E.g. 2-4 days post surgery where the patient cannto drink

What is the treatment for alcohol withdrawal? 

{{c1::Benzodiazepines}}

What is the treatment for delirium tremens? 

{{c1::Benzodiazepines}}
e.g. chlordiazepoxide, lorazepam
{{c1::Methadone}} is a long-acting oral opiate used for opioid detoxification or long-term maintenance therapy
Non-specific symptoms of {{c1::stimulant}} intoxication (stimulant or depressant) include psychomotor agitation, tachycardia, arrhythmias and anxiety
Non-specific symptoms of {{c1::stimulant}} withdrawal (stimulant or depressant) include post-use "crash", depression, lethargy, and hypersomnia/weight gain
also may have sleep disturbances and vivid nightmares

What drug intoxication presents as pupillary dilation, grandiosity, vasospasm, and paranoia that lasts for less than one hour? 

{{c1::Cocaine}}
important distinguishing feature from amphetamines, which have a longer duration

What is the treatment for cocaine intoxication? 

{{c1::benzodiazepines}}, {{c2::α-blockers}}
note: β-blockers are contraindicated

What drug intoxication presents as violence, psychomotor agitation, analgesia, and nystagmus? 

{{c1::Phencyclidine (PCP)}}

- patients initially may appear catatonic and rigid (PCP is a sedative hypnotic / dissociative anesthetic) that generally acts as a downer, but can these patients can quickly become violent and have superhuman strength

- also may present with impulsivity, tachycardia, hypertension, psychosis, delirium, and seizures

What eye movement is associated with phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication? 

{{c1::Nystagmus}}

What is the most common complication of PCP intoxication? 

{{c1::Trauma}}

What is the treatment for PCP intoxication? 

{{c1::benzodiazepines}}, {{c2::rapid-acting antipsychotics}}

What drug intoxication presents as perceptual distortion (visual, auditory), depersonalization, and possible flashbacks? 

{{c1::LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide)}}
also may present with anxiety, paranoia, and psychosis

What drug intoxication presents as conjunctival injection, tachycardia, increased appetite, paranoid delusions, and dry mouth? 

{{c1::Marijuana}}

also may present with euphoria, anxiety, perception of slowed time, impaired judgment, social withdrawal, and hallucinations 

marijuana produces effects that last 1-4 hours by stimulating (THC - active compound) cannabinoid receptors (CB1 and CB2)
Marijuana withdrawal may cause irritability, anxiety, depression, insomnia, and {{c1::decreased}} appetite

What drug intoxication presents as disinhibition, heightened emotional/tactile sensation, and teeth clenching? 

{{c1::MDMA (ecstasy)}}
also may present with euphoria, distorted sensory and time perception, hyperactivity, hypertension, hyperthermia, hyponatremia
Guillain-Barre syndrome results in {{c1::inflammation}} and segmental {{c2::demyelination}} of peripheral nerves and motor fibers

- Including cranial nerves III-XII

- endoneurial inflammatory infiltrate will be seen light microscopy

Neuropsychiatric symptoms of cirrhosis include hepatic {{c1::encephalopathy}} and
 {{c2::asterixis ("flapping tremor")}}

Is hepatic encephalopathy reversible or irreversible? 

{{c1::Reversible}}
Hepatic encephalopathy may be triggered by increased NH3 production or absorption, such as increased dietary {{c1::protein}}
other causes include GI bleed, constipation, and infection
Hepatic encephalopathy may be triggered by decreased NH3 removal, such as {{c1::renal}} failure
other causes include diuretics and bypassed hepatic blood flow post-TIPS

What antibiotics (2) are used to treat hepatic encephalopathy? 

{{c1::rifaximin and neomycin}}
decreases NH3 producing gut bacteria

What osmotic laxative is used to treat hepatic encephalopathy? 

{{c1::Lactulose}}

Lactulose is metabolized in the colon by colonic bacteria to monosaccharides, and then to volatile fatty acids, hydrogen, and methane. Lactulose reduces intestinal ammonia production and absorption in three ways. First, the colonic metabolism of sugars causes a laxative effect via an increase in intraluminal gas formation and osmolality which leads to a reduction in transit time and intraluminal pH. This laxative effect is also beneficial for constipation.[7] Next, lactulose promotes increased uptake of ammonia by colonic bacteria which utilize the trapped colonic ammonia as a nitrogen source for protein synthesis. The reduction of intestinal pH facilitates this process, which favors the conversion of ammonia (NH3) produced by the gut bacteria, to ammonium (NH4+),[8][9][10] an ionized form of the molecule, unable to cross biological membranes. Finally, lactulose also causes a reduction in intestinal production of ammonia. The acidic pH destroys urease-producing bacteria involved in the production of ammonia.  The unabsorbed disaccharide also inhibits intestinal glutaminase activity, which blocks the intestinal uptake of glutamine, and its metabolism to ammonia.

What type of drug are deferasirox, deferoxamine, and deferiprone (oral)?

{{c1::Iron chelators}}

What GI disorder may be treated with deferasirox, deferoxamine, and oral deferiprone?  

{{c1::Hemochromatosis}}
Hepatic {{c1::angiosarcoma}} is a malignant tumor associated with exposure to arsenic and vinyl chloride
tumor cells express CD31 (PECAM1) which is an endothelial cell marker
Treatment of portosystemic shunts with TIPS can precipitate {{c1::hepatic encephalopathy}} in cirrhotic patients
the transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) bypasses the liver
Terminal Complement (C5-C9) Deficiencies increase susceptibility to recurrent {{c1::Neisseria}} bacteremia
These patients most often present with recurrent meningitis
Risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma of skin include {{c1::immunosuppressive}} therapy, {{c2::arsenic}} poisoning, and chronic inflammation (e.g. draining sinus tract)
Aspirin inhibits cyclooxygenase via irreversible covalent {{c1::acetylation}} of serine residues
Thus is the preferred anti-platelet drug out of the NSAIDS (the rest are reversible)

What acid-base disorder is seen with early phases of aspirin toxicity? 

{{c1::Respiratory alkalosis}}
Salicylates stimulate respiratory drive by stimulating the medullary respiratory center

What acid-base disorder is seen with late phases of aspirin toxicity? 

{{c1::High anion gap metabolic acidosis}}
At this point, patients have a mixed anion gap metabolic acidosis + concomitant respiratory alkalosis
{{c2::Aspirin}} is an NSAID that is associated with {{c1::tinnitus}} (ear) as an adverse effect

tinnitus is a rare side effect
- alters cochlear nerve function
- usually occurs with very high doses
- resolves with discontinuation
Aspirin toxicity may treated be with {{c1::alkalinization}} of serum/urine
e.g. NaHCO3; alkalinization of serum pulls aspirin out of CNS; alkalinization of the urine promotes salicylate excretion
Acetaminophen exerts its effects via {{c1::reversible}} inhibition of cyclooxygenase (reversible or irreversible)
cyclooxygenase makes prostaglandins

Is acetaminophen useful as an anti-inflammatory agent?

{{c1::No}}

What toxic intermediate is formed by in small amounts by metabolism of acetaminophen? 

{{c1::NAPQI}}
Acetaminophen toxicity results in depletion of hepatic {{c1::glutathione}} stores by NAPQI

What is the antidote for acetaminophen poisoning? 

{{c1::N-acetylcysteine}}
brandname: Mucomyst
N-acetylcysteine helps restore {{c1::reduced glutathione}} stores in the setting of acetaminophen toxicity
thus N-acetylcysteine is a reducing agent

Which immune cell has the cell surface protein CD40L? 

{{c1::Helper T cells}}
Postive impact on T cell activation

What pathologic RBC finding is seen in a peripheral smear with lead poisoning, sideroblastic anemia, and myelodysplastic syndrome? 

{{c1::Basophilic stippling}}
versus ringed sideroblasts which are seen in bone marrow

Basophilic stippling in RBCs is a result of aggregationof {{c1::residual ribosomes}}

- seen with{{c2:: lead poisoning}}, {{c3::sideroblastic}} anemia, and {{c4::myelodysplastic syndromes}}

- due to inhibition of erythrocyte 5' nucleotidase, which prevents ability to degrade RNA resulting in ribosome aggregation

Sideroblastic anemia, or sideroachrestic anemia, is a form of anemia in which the bone marrow produces ringed sideroblasts rather than healthy red blood cells (erythrocytes).

Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) are a group of cancers in which immature blood cells in the bone marrow do not mature and therefore do not become healthy blood cells.[3] Early on, there are typically no symptoms.[3] Later symptoms may include feeling tired, shortness of breath, easy bleeding, or frequent infections.[3] Some types may develop into acute myeloid leukemia.[3]
Iron poisoning causes cell death due to {{c1::peroxidation}} of membrane lipids
often occurs due to accidental ingestion by children (adult tablets may look like candy)

Which blood transfusion therapy is used to increase coagulation factor levels?

{{c1::fresh frozen plasma (FFP) or prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC)}}

-These can be used to correct deficiencies of any clotting factor (PT/PTT will normalize after infusion)

used for DIC, cirrhosis, and immediate anticoagulation reversal 

- FFP is plasma after removal of RBCs, WBCs, platelets; frozen for storage - once thawed must be used within 24 hours since clotting factors degrade

- FFP contains all coagulation factors and plasma proteins; PCC generally contains Factors II (thrombin), VII, IX, X, Protein C& S

What toxin is found in pufferfish?

{{c1::Tetrodotoxin}}
Saxitoxin, which works in the exact same manner, is found in dinoflaggelates in the "red tide"
Tetrodotoxin and Saxitoxin bind fast voltage-gated {{c1::Na+}} channels in cardiac/nerve tissue, preventing depolarization

Binds to v-gated sodium channels in nerve / cardiac tissue, preventing sodium influx and depolarization

severe exposures can cause severe hypotension, general paralysis, death can occur from respiratory failure / hypotension

Do tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin cause or prevent depolarization? 

{{c1::Prevent}}
Saxitoxin is found in the "red tide" and is made by dinoflaggelates

What toxin is found in reef fish (e.g. Barracuda, snapper, and moray eel)?

{{c1::Ciguatoxin}}
Batrachotoxin, a toxin that works in the exact same manner, is found in South american frogs
Ciguatoxin and batrachotoxin open {{c1::Na+}} channels, causing depolarization

Do ciguatoxin or batrachotoxin cause or prevent depolarization? 

{{c1::Causes depolarization}}

What toxin is found in spoiled dark-meat fish (e.g. tuna, mahi-mahi, mackerel, bonito)?

{{c1::Histamine (scombroid poisoning)}}

This is bc at temperatures above 60*F, bacterial histidine decarboxylase produced by symbiotic bacteria (like morganella) converts histidine (found in plenty in fish) to histamine. Therefore store fish in freezer, bc histamine will not be degraded from cooking heat temperatures

What are the treatments (2) for arsenic and mercury poisoning?

{{c1::dimercaprol and succimer}}

Which carcinogen is associated with the following types of cancer?

{{c1::Arsenic}} 

Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Skin
Angiosarcoma of the Liver
Lung Cancer

- Arsenic likes to bind to cysteine residues in keratin (explaining predilection for causing SCC of the skin), thus the presence of this compound can be detected by sampling a patients fingernails or hair

Nowadays, patients typically can get chronically exposed to Arsenic in a couple of different situations, including:
(1) - {{c1::cigarette}} smoke
(2) - {{c2::Herbicides}} used in vineyards
(3) - metal {{c3::smelting}}

(2) - also used as a pesticide in Asia
(3) - specifically, melting of zinc or copper ores

you can test for arsenic poisoning in patients by testing fingernails / hair

acute exposures are insecticides / contaminated water

Treating an organophosphate poisoning is two fold; {{c1::Atropine}} which inhibits all subtypes of {{c1::muscarinic receptors}}, and {{c2::Pralidoximine}}, which if given early - regenerates {{c2::AChE}}

- Organophosphates induce Cholinergic Toxicity

- organophosphates bind to the acetylcholinesterase active site, pralidoxime also binds to the active site, binds organophosphate (if bind hasn’t aged), then the organophosphate + pralidoxime complex dissociates
Deferoxamine, deferasirox, and deferiprone are {{c2::iron}} {{c1::chelators}}
Think Defer --> De-Fer --> De-Iron (removing the iron)
Iron chelators are indicated for {{c1::secondary hemochromatosis}} and {{c2::iron poisoning}}

Iron chelators = deferasirox, deferoxamine, deferiprone

Iron chelators are used in secondary hemochromatosis as opposed to primary as phlebotomy is not suggested when a patient already needs transfusions of blood

Secondary Hemochromatosis. Secondary hemochromatosis occurs when a buildup of iron is brought on by other medical conditions,

Drugs that elongate QT interval must be avoided in Congenital Long QT Syndrome -  ABCDEF+N

A - anti-arrthymics (Class {{c1::1A}} and {{c1::3)}}; {{c2::Arsenic::heavy metal?}}
B - anti-biotics ({{c3::macrolides}}, {{c3::fluoroquinolones}})
C - anti-"c"ychotics ({{c4::haloperidol}}); {{c5::chloroquine}}
D - anti-depressants ({{c6::TCAs}}); diuretics ({{c7::thiazides}})
E - anti-e{{c8::metics}} 
F - anti-fungals ({{c9::fluconazole}})
N - -n{{c10::avir (protease inhibitors)::drug for HIV}}
A 3rd generation cephalosporin (Ceftriaxone) indicated for patients who have Lyme disease that is {{c1::disseminated}}
If a patient presents to you with <u>Lyme disease</u>, your first line drug is {{c1::Doxycycline}}
Flucytosine is primarily used for {{c1::cryptococcal}} meningitis
Give in combination with Amphotericin B

{{c1::Flucon}}azole is used for:

- candidal infections of all types

- chronic suppression of cryptococcal meningitis in AIDS patients
Amphotericin can be used for certain protozoal infections, particularly {{c1::Leishmaniasis}} and {{c2::Naegleria Fowleri}}
- However, Amphotericin has been effective for only a few survivors of Naegleria Fowleri (Primary Amebic Encephalitis)

Are Acyclovir, Famciclovir, Valacyclovir used to treat both HSV-induced mucocutaneous and genital lesions as well as for encephalitis?

{{c1::Yes}}

Which thyroid imbalance presents with puffy facies and generalized nonpitting edema?

{{c1::Hypothyroidism}}

This is known as Myxedema; TSH stimulates dermal fibroblasts to deposit GAGs in interstitial spaces; hyaluronic acid provides an osmotic stimulus to draw water into deposits and cause this presentation

The urinary cyanide-nitroprusside test is diagnostic for which renal disease? 

{{c1::Cystinuria}}
Lead poisoning presents in adults with environmental exposure (batteries, ammunition) with headache and memory loss due to {{c1::demyelination}}, as well as {{c2::abdominal}} colic
Can result in wrist / foot drop as well as fanconi syndrome

What drug should you avoid in delirium?

{{c1::benzodiazepines}}
This is NOT the case for delirium tremens where benzodiazepines are indicated
Stimulant intoxication can present with {{c1::paranoid}} ideation and thus must be differentiated from primary psychiatric disorders
physical signs include tachycardia, hypertension, hyperthermia, diaphroesis, and mydriasis
Phencyclidine (PCP) is a hallucinogen that works primarily as an {{c1::NMDA}} receptor antagonist
secondarily, inhibits the reuptake of NE, dopamine, serotonin; also stimulates sigma-opioid receptors
Cyanide poisoning is usually due to {{c1::inhalation}} injury

Ex. due to fires, cyanide is released in the burning of plastics, wool, and plants (Ex. cassava)

Another cause is rodenticides ("gopher goiter")
Cyanide inhibits {{c1::aerobic}} metabolism, resulting in hypoxia unresponsive to {{c2::supplemental O2}}
Decreased aerobic metabolism leads to increased anaerobic metabolism --> lactic acidosis and increased AG metabolic acidosis
Patients with cyanide poisoning present with an "almond" breath odor and {{c1::reddish}} skin discoloration

Patients also are tachypneic, tachycardic, and often are nauseated, vomit, are confused and weak

This is rapidly fatal if untreated
Many patients with inhalation injury present secondary to {{c1::burns}}, CO inhalation, cyanide poisoning, or {{c2::arsenic}} poisoning

What is the treatment for Tetrodotoxin and Ciguatoxin poisoning?

{{c1::Supportive care}}
additionally, intestinal decontamination with gut lavage and charcoal
Patients with cyanide poisoning have a {{c1::narrowing}} of the venous-arterial PO2 gradient
This is because the tissue is unable to extract arterial oxygen
Patients with {{c4::vertebral osteomyelitis}} and {{c3::epidural abscess}} will present with {{c1::focal}} back tenderness and {{c2::<u>constitutional</u>}} symptoms

- constitutional symptoms = fever, night sweats, weight loss; these patients will have a history of recent infection, IVDU, or immuno compromise

- if neurological symptoms are present consider epidural abscess over veterbral osteomylitis and vice versa otherwise

CLOSE contacts (roommates, family in the same household, healthcare workers with intimate close contact) of patients with {{c1::menigitis}} should be given prophylaxis
{{c2::Rifampin 300mg x 4 doses}}
{{c3::Ciprofloxacin 500mg x 1 dose}}
{{c4::Ceftriaxone IM in pregnant women}}
Listeria Meningitis occurs in patient within {{c1::extremes of age}} and {{c2::patients with cell mediated immunosuppression}} such as {{c3::Hodgkin’s disease,}} {{c4::HIV}}, {{c5::PREGNANCY}}

Recurrent Meningitis typically is caused by 
{{c7::Parameningeal focus - infection}}, {{c6::epidermoid cyst}}, {{c5::craniopharyngioma}}
{{c4::CSF leak, often following trauma}}
Pneumococcus most common
{{c3::Mollaret’s – Recurrent HSV, epidermoid cyst?}}
{{c2::Terminal compliment deficiencies with recurrent meningococcus}}
{{c1::SLE, migraines}}

Usual Aseptic Culprits of Meningitis
{{c7::
Enteroviruses (Echo, coxsackie, polio, etc.)
}}
{{c6::
Herpes (HSV, VZV, EBV, CMV)}}
{{c5::
Arboviruses (West Nile)}}
{{c4::
Lyme disease}}
{{c3::
Adenovirus}}
{{c2::Lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus}}
{{c1::Possible spirochetes? (leptospira, neurosyphilis, borrelia, etc.)}}
West Nile Virus aka {{c1::Flavivirus}}, causes {{c2::flaccid paralysis}} and has a {{c3::2-15 day}} incubation period
West Nile Virus is diagnosed by {{c1::Serologies for WNV}}  and {{c2::IgM, IgG in the blood}}

West Nile Virus infection is associated with
{{c1::1. Transplantation}}
{{c2::2. Transfusion}}
{{c3::3. Breastfeeding}}
{{c4::4. Transplacental transmission}}
{{c5::5. Occupational exposure}}

{{c1::Neurologic Lyme Disease}} is caused by infection from {{c2::Borrelia burgdorferi}} – only organism of the spirochetes (also leptospira and Treponema) that can be visualized with {{c3::Wright or Giemsa stain}} due to size
{{c2::Neurologic Lyme Disease}} is the most {{c1::common tick borne infection}} in the United States
{{c2::Neurologic Lyme disease}} is characterized by {{c1::"Expanding "target" rash }}called {{c2::erythema migrans}}
{{c4::Brain Abscess}} presents classically with {{c1::headache}}, {{c1::high fever}} and is commonly in patient with {{c2::bad dentition}} and {{c3::IV drug users}}

Brain abscess is typically caused by {{c1::anaerobs}} such as {{c2::Staph aureus (in trauma / IV drug users) }} and {{c3::fungal}} infections such as {{c4::Mucormycosis}}, {{c5::Candida}}, {{c6::Aspergillus}}
{{c4::HSV Encephalitis}} presents with {{c1::Fever}}, {{c2::bizarre behavior}}, {{c3::focal TEMPORAL lobe findings including seizure and MRI abnormalities}}
{{c1::S. aureus including MRSA}} is the most common source of infection in {{c2::Epidural Abscess}}
{{c1::Primary Amebic Encephalitis}} is typically caused by {{c2::Naegleria fowleri}}
{{c1::Primary Amebic Encephalitis}} presents in patients who {{c2::swim in warm, fresh water for extended periods of time}}. These patients typically have changes in sense of {{c2::taste and smell }}
